RECORD.TEXT: 417244133 08673735 936462 1/31/1990 12:00:00 AM Discharge Summary DIS 01/31/1990 Report Status : Unsigned 02/06/1990 DIAGNOSES : CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE . PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE . The patient is a 61 year old white male , who presented with a 2 to 3 week history of increasing exertional angina and rest angina . He has a history of peripheral vascular disease . The chest pain is associated with shortness of breath , and if exertional , it often improves with rest . There is no nausea , vomiting or diaphoresis . More recently the chest pain episodes have lasted up to 1 hour . On the day of admission in Rogas Medical Center medical doctor 's office , the patient had 2 episodes of chest pain associated with shortness of breath without radiation or other associated symptoms . Those episodes responded promptly to 1 sublingual nitroglycerin . Of note , the patient had an exercise tolerance test on 9-7-89 , that was terminated at 6 minutes due to fatigue , where he reached a maximum heart rate of 131 , with a maximal blood pressure of 190/80 . There were no arrhythmias , no ST changes to suggest ischemia . The REVIEW OF SYSTEMS is positive for claudication with 1 flight of stairs and for nocturia every 2 hours . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY is significant for diabetes mellitus , peripheral vascular disease , nephrolithiasis , psoriasis , diabetic peripheral neuropathy with paresthesias . MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION were NPH 50 units every morning , and Excedrin 1 by mouth every 4 hours as needed for paresthesias . There are no known drug ALLERGIES . He does not smoke and drinks alcohol only occasionally . FAMILY HISTORY is positive for a brother who died at age 62 of a cerebrovascular accident , a brother 60 years old with coronary artery disease , and a brother at 55 with coronary artery disease . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : His blood pressure was 112/70 , heart rate 80 , respiratory rate 18 , and he was afebrile . His skin was warm and dry with alopecia on the lower extremities bilaterally below the knees . Head , eyes , ears , nose and throat examination was normal . His chest was clear with equal breath sounds throughout . There was no jugular venous distention . He had a regular rate and rhythm with a normal S1 , S2 , no murmurs , clicks , gallops or rubs . His extremities revealed no cyanosis , clubbing or edema . Pulses were II / II throughout , except for the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis , which were 0/II . Admission sodium was 140 , potassium 4.6 , chloride 108 , bicarbonate 26 , blood urea nitrogen 15 , creatinine 1.0 , glucose 234 . Cholesterol was 237 , albumin 4.3 , calcium 9.8 . Hematocrit was 39.7 , white blood cell count 9.1 , platelets 202,000 , prothrombin time 12.4 , partial thromboplastin time 26.9 . There was mild flattening in V5 and V6 . The patient ruled out for myocardial infarction by enzymes and electrocardiogram . He had multiple episodes during hospitalization of chest pain radiating to the back , during which his vital signs remained stable and there were no electrocardiogram changes . His pain resolved with nitroglycerin sublingually and occasional MSO4 intravenously . An exercise tolerance test was performed and the patient went 7 minutes 6 seconds and was terminated secondary to fatigue . There was no chest pain , his peak heart rate was 150 , peak blood pressure 160/80 . At the end of the test and in recovery , the patient had 1-mm of ST depressions in the inferolateral leads . There were no arrhythmias . Thallium demonstrated inferior , septal and apical filling defects with redistribution . Given his rest pain and the results of the thallium , the patient went to catheterization , which demonstrated a left anterior descending with diffuse disease , a 60% proximal and 80% distal stenosis , obtuse marginal branch #2 with an 80% proximal stenosis , left anterior descending D1 80% , left anterior descending D2 80% . A percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty was performed on the obtuse marginal branch #2 , with stenosis going from 80% to 20% . Post-percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty the patient had recurrence of his chest pain and was returned for catheterization , which demonstrated patency of the obtuse marginal branch #2 . The patient was started on diltiazem and Isordil and remained pain-free on these medications . Problem #2 was diabetes mellitus . The patient 's blood sugars remained well-controlled with diet and 50 units of NPH every morning . Problem #3 was fatigue . Neurology consultation was obtained and the opinion of the neurologist was that the pain was not secondary to muscle weakness . Likely the fatigue is multifactorial . He may benefit from a trial of tricyclic antidepressants . DISPOSITION : The patient was discharged on 2-6-90 . MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE were Ecotrin 1 by mouth per day , NPH 50 units every morning , diltiazem 90 mg by mouth 4 times a day , Isordil 20 mg by mouth 3 times a day , nitroglycerin 1/150 1 sublingual as needed for chest pain .
